slides.title: Reserves review fa
slides.originalNotes:
Reserves review
Remember that a reserve line can be thought of as an account set aside for one specific aspct of exposure processing. It contains both credits and debits, and its size is equal to the credits minus the debits. It is money set aside for payments that are expected related to a specific exposure.

There is no technical requirement for an exposure to have a reserve line. You can create and even close exposures without creating reserve lines. However, you cannot make payments to claimants without reserve lines attached to an exposure.

Reserve lines are defined by the exposure, cost type, and the cost category. An exposure may have multiple reserve lines.

In this example, the exposure on the Medical Details coverage for Jim Means has two separate reserve lines; one for the Claim Cost with a category of Medical, and the second for Claim Expense with a category of Case management.

slides.title: Creating and changing reserves (3 of 4)
slides.originalNotes:
Creating and changing reserves (3 of 4)
When you modify an existing reserve line, ClaimCenter creates a reserve transaction for the value of the difference. For example, if the original reserve line is $2000 and you change it to $2500, there is a new S500 reserve transaction created. This is true for adding or subtracting from the reserve line. Remember that the total of the reserve line shown on ClaimCenter screens is a sum of all the transactions for that reserve line.

slides.title: Eroding payments review (1 of 3)
slides.originalNotes:
Eroding payments review (I of 3)
Eroding payments reduce the amount of the reserve line total by the amount of the payment This gives the insurer an accurate accounting of theamount remaining on that reserve line that they may have to pay for the claim.

When the reserve line total is displayed, the amount is the sum of all the reserve transactions, minus the eroding payment transactions. Remember that the
total remaining is always calculated at runtime.

Eroding payments review (3 of 3)
A final payment creates a payment transaction and creates a transaction that reduces the total of the reserve line to zero. In this example, the final payment of $1465 leaves a balance of $335. Because it was flagged as a final payment, ClaimCenter creates areserve transaction of -S335which brings the reserve line total to zero.

If a payment is non-eroding, then the payment does not cause the amount of money in the reserve line to decrease. In this case, the only transactions that are created are payments.

slides.title: What is a check?
slides.originalNotes:
What is a check?
In ClaimCenter, checks are payments or transfers of funds from one or more reserve lines to a claimant or other third party. Checks may be actual checks or Electronic Funds Transfers. Checks, or payments, may be to one or more parties. For example, a payment for a Homeowners claim may made payable to the homeowner and the mortgage company. A single check may also be for multiple payments. For example, a payment may include reimbursement for medical bills as well as towing or car rental.

Every check, whether it is a single check or part of multiple checks, is always part of a checkset.

slides.title: Payment wizard (1 of 3)
slides.originalNotes:
Payment wizard (1 of 3)
Checks, or payments, are created using the Payment Wizard. When you start thepayment wizard, you create a checkset. Initially, the checkset is empty, meaning that no checks are in the checkset.

During this first step, you specify the number payees which determines the number of checks. For example, if the payment is split between theclaimant and their attomey, there will be two payees and two checks. If there are multiple payees, then you must specify the amount of money that will go to each of the secondary payees This is specified either as a percentage or as a fixed amount. When you specify the payees, you also may edit the payment method and delivery address if the payment is a check or the bank account and routing number if it is an Electronic Funds Transfer.

You can also specify joint payees which makes the single check payable to both parties. An example of joint payees would bea homeowners claim where the check is payable to the homeowner and the mortgage company.

slides.title: Automatic payments (recurring payments)
slides.originalNotes:
Automatic payments (recurring payments)
In the base application, there are a series of fields that appear in the "Set check instructions" step only if the check is automatic or EFT These fields let you specify additional information that the automatic or electronic system can take advantage of.

For Workers' Comp, you can specify the service period, which is the period of time over which a payment represented in a check is eamed.

Identifying service periods is useful when handling an IW who first receives TTD, then TPD and then potentially PPD. Each mayinvolve different payment amounts and periods of time.

The most common example of a check's service period is found in workers' compensation claims. A primary type of loss in this kind of claim is for the worker's lost wages. In this case, the insured is entitled to all or part of the wages they would have earned had they been physically able to work. For example, if that periodof time was from August 1 — 14, the check's service period would be August 1 — 14. The payment in the check identifies the time period over which the damage— in this case, lost wages— occurred.

slides.title: Check processing integration
slides.originalNotes:
Check processing Integration
ClaimCenter does not have a check writing or Electronic Funds Transfer issuing process. It uses a built-in integration point to connect to an external check processing system. These systems process checks andElectronic Funds Transfers based on the data received from ClaimCenter- The data exchange begins with ClaimCenter sending check or Electronic Funds Transfer information like the amount, line items, check memos, payees, and so on. It also receives back from the integrated system the check status like requesting, requested, issued, and so on.

slides.title: The life cycle of a check
slides.originalNotes:
The life cycle of a check
Creating a check, or payment, results in a check or Electronic Funds Transfer which goes through a number of phases in its lifecycle. The lifecycle isimportant because different actions can be taken at different phases of a lifecycle. For example, you can't delete a check once it has been issued. However, a check can be deleted if it is in the awaiting submission phase.

slides.title: The life cycle of a check - Step 7
slides.originalNotes:
The life cycle of a check — Step 7
The last phase or status is when the payee or payees have cashed the check, or the Electronic Funds Transfer is complete. When that happens, the external check processing system notifies ClaimCenter to set the status to Cleared.

The Pending Approval, Rejected, and Awaiting Submission statuses are managed by ClaimCenter- The external check processing system largely manages the latter three steps, identifying that the check has been received, processed, and then cashed.

slides.title: The life cycle of a check - Step 8
slides.originalNotes:
The life cycle of a check — Step 8
There are specific times in the lifecycle of a check when a user may take actions on a check. While a check is in Awaiting Submission status, it may be edited or even deleted. Remember that in Awaiting Submission, it has not been sent to the external check processing system by the batch process. After it has been sent and the status is still Requesting or Requested, which means that it has not yet been issued, the payment may be voided.

Once the check has reached issued status, it may be stopped or voided. Generally, a check is voided if it is still in the possession of the issuer. Once it has left the issuer, then it may only be stopped.

The principal is based on a physical check, but the concepts apply to a check or an ElectronicFunds Transfer. If an ElectronicFunds Transfer has not be sent, then it can be voided. Once it has been sent, it should only be stopped.

questionData.question: A check includes a $200 final payment from a $500 reserve line. Why does ClaimCenter create a second transaction? What is the dollar amount of this transaction?
questionData.answer: The second transaction is used to zero out the reserve line. The dollar amount of this transaction will be -$300, since there is $300 remaining after the $200 payment transaction.
